bestBHT.bht: Upon hearing the cries of the blind men, Jesus commanded that they be brought to Him. Demonstrating His power and compassion, He stood still and acknowledged Himself as the Son of David. Those around the blind men encouraged them, saying that Jesus was calling them. In response to Jesus' question, the blind men eagerly threw away their garments, showing their faith and readiness to approach Him. Jesus, in His kindness, was willing to grant their desires, further revealing His undeserved goodness towards them and all the people.

Henry Alford: 32.] called them = (literally) “said, call ye him” Mark, “commanded him to be brought” Luke.
John Calvin: He gently and kindly asks what they desire; for he had determined to grant their requests.
Christ puts the question to them, not for their sake as individuals, but for the sake of all the people.
Christ was induced to cure them, not only by undeserved goodness, but because he pitied their distress.
Philip Schaff: He now allows Himself to be publicly called: ‘Son of David;’ comp. His previous conduct in a similar case (chap. Matthew 9:27-28)."
Mark adds that those about the blind man said: ‘Be of good courage, rise; He calleth thee,’ showing that they too responded to the Lord’s compassion.
John Gill: Made a full stop, when he was near, or right against where these blind men sat; which shows the strength of faith, the force of prayer, and the great regard Christ has to both.

This question he put, not as being ignorant of their desires, but to show both his power and willingness to do anything for them they should ask; and that their faith in him might be made manifest, and the people have their expectations raised, and they prepared to attend the miracle now to be wrought.
Upon which they threw away their garments, their long upper garments, which were some hindrance to a quick motion, at least Bartimaeus did; that they might be the sooner with him.

bhtAttempts.bht: Jesus, upon hearing those who were blind crying out to Him, commanded them to be brought to Him. He stood still and allowed Himself to be publicly called the Son of David. Those around the blind men encouraged them, saying, Be of good courage, rise; He calleth thee. Jesus, in His kindness and compassion, asked them what they desired. He already knew their desires, but He wanted to demonstrate His power and willingness to grant their requests, to reveal their faith in Him, and to raise the expectations of the people. The blind men, eager and filled with faith, threw away their garments and quickly approached Him.

Upon hearing the cries of the blind men, Jesus commanded them to be brought to Him. He allowed Himself to be publicly called the Son of David, standing still in response. As those around the blind men encouraged them, Jesus, in His kindness and compassion, asked what they desired, even though He already knew. This served to demonstrate His power and willingness, reveal their faith, and raise the expectations of the people. Filled with faith, the blind men eagerly approached Him, throwing away their garments.

Jesus, upon hearing the cries of the blind men, commanded that they be brought to Him. He stood still as they approached, publicly acknowledging Himself as the Son of David. Those around the blind men encouraged them, letting them know that Jesus was calling them. In His compassion, Jesus asked the blind men what they desired, even though He already knew. This allowed Him to demonstrate His power, reveal their faith, and raise the expectations of the people. The blind men, filled with faith, eagerly discarded their garments and approached Jesus.

Upon hearing the cries of the blind men, Jesus commanded them to be brought to Him. He responded by standing still and publically acknowledging Himself as the Son of David. Those around the blind men encouraged them, telling them that Jesus was calling them. In His compassion, Jesus asked the blind men what they desired, even though He already knew. This allowed Him to demonstrate His power, reveal their faith, and raise the expectations of the people. Filled with faith, the blind men eagerly approached and discarded their garments.

Upon hearing the cries of the blind men, Jesus commanded that they be brought to Him. Demonstrating His power and compassion, He stood still and acknowledged Himself as the Son of David. Those around the blind men encouraged them, saying that Jesus was calling them. In response to Jesus' question, the blind men eagerly threw away their garments, showing their faith and readiness to approach Him. Jesus, in His kindness, was willing to grant their desires, further revealing His undeserved goodness towards them and all the people.
